claim: In the case of Figure 1A, when ARS is dissolved in an aqueous electrolyte solution and purged with argon, the pH was measured to be 5, and the ARS exhibited a two‐electron reduction and oxidation that occur in two separate steps.
title: Figure 1.
caption: The cyclic voltammetry performed with a glassy carbon working electrode, Ag/AgCl reference electrode, and a platinum counter electrode of (A) ARS in a 0.1 M KCl in H2O solution purged with argon and CO2 at 100 mV/s scan rate; (B) pH 1 achieved with HCl dropped into a 0.1 M KCl in H2O solution, pH 7 achieved with a potassium dihydrate orthophosphate buffer in a 0.1 M KCl in H2O solution, and pH 13 achieved with a 0.1 M KOH in H2O solution – all solutions purged with argon and measured at 100 mV/s (C) potassium hexacyanoferrate (II)/(III) in a 0.1 M KCl in H2O solution with scan rates from 25 to 400 mV/s.

claim: The DAC absorption and desorption cycling results are shown in Figure 2 along with the humidity and temperature conditions.
title: Figure 2.
caption: CO2 concentration, temperature, and relative humidity for the exit stream of air purged through the catholyte solution at a flow rate of 20 mL/min. CO2 capture performed using 50 mL of 20 mM ARS, 1 M Nicotinamide, 1 M KCl aqueous catholyte and 50 mL of 40 mM K4[Fe(CN)6], 1 M KCl aqueous anolyte.

claim:
Critically, due to the nature of the CO2 capture mechanism, the system can operate in very humid conditions, which is a considerable hurdle for many temperature‐swing DAC systems.
[25]
 As seen in Figure 2, the capture and release of CO2 was highly repeatable over more than 72 hours of continuous testing.
title: Figure 2.
caption: CO2 concentration, temperature, and relative humidity for the exit stream of air purged through the catholyte solution at a flow rate of 20 mL/min. CO2 capture performed using 50 mL of 20 mM ARS, 1 M Nicotinamide, 1 M KCl aqueous catholyte and 50 mL of 40 mM K4[Fe(CN)6], 1 M KCl aqueous anolyte.

claim:
Coulombic efficiency was calculated for each cycle based on the amount of charge passed during the charge cycle (sorption) divided by the amount of charged passed during the discharge cycle (desorption).
[26]
 Alternatively, capacity retention is defined as the amount of charge passed on the discharge cycle of cycle n relative to the amount of charge passed on the discharge cycle of n+1.
[26]
 From the charge/discharge voltage curves in Figure 3, it is evident that, much like the CO2 capture experiments, the charging and discharging of the system are highly repeatable without much deviation.
title: Figure 3.
caption: Charge/Discharge curves for the 16 cycles (72 hours) electrochemical DAC experiments performed with 50 mL of 20 mM ARS, 1 M Nicotinamide, 1 M KCl aqueous catholyte and 50 mL of 40 mM K4[Fe(CN)6], 1 M KCl aqueous anolyte.

claim: Given the high coulombic efficiency and capacity retention metrics exhibited during CO2 capture testing, we attempted to replicate the experiment in longer term electrochemical cycling measurements, as shown in Figure 4.
title: Figure 4.
caption: Charge/discharge capacity and coulombic efficiency through 100 cycles (205 hours) of continuous testing with 50 mL of 20 mM ARS, 1 M Nicotinamide, 1 M KCl aqueous catholyte and 50 mL of 40 mM K4[Fe(CN)6], 1 M KCl aqueous anolyte.

claim: Initial CFD simulations of the unmodified flow field (Figure 5A) showed that the solution′s velocity vectors linearly followed the path of the flow field with minimal mixing along the z‐axis.
title: Figure 5.
caption: CFD simulations of water flowing through (A) the unmodified flow field (B) the modified flow field with agitators.

claim: The most turbulent portions of the unmodified flow field were at the end of each linear section (Figure 5A).
title: Figure 5.
caption: CFD simulations of water flowing through (A) the unmodified flow field (B) the modified flow field with agitators.

claim: In these areas, solution would flow up or down the triangular ramp, hit the middle agitator and cause circular solution mixing (Figure 5B).
title: Figure 5.
caption: CFD simulations of water flowing through (A) the unmodified flow field (B) the modified flow field with agitators.

claim: To assess the techno‐economic viability of an ARS/K4[(FeCN)6] DAC process, we performed a discounted cash flow for the 10 year operation of a demonstration‐scale version of our DAC process – accounting for maintenance and periodic full replacement of the solvent system, fuel cells, and pumps (Figure 6).
title: Figure 6.
caption: Breakdown of the levelized cost constituents for electrochemical DAC per tonne of CO2.

claim: As seen in Figure 7, we performed a sensitivity analysis of 9 key factors to determine their uncertainty and influence on the LCOC.
title: Figure 7.
caption: Tornado analysis of the most influential cost factors.
